pullRequest.title: Initial check in of MessageImpl refactoring
pullRequest.bodyText: Looking at a simple ping REST throughput test, there's a lot of processing around the HashMap operations in MessageImpl. Make explicit getters and setters to avoid hashCode and equals calls.

nodes.bodyText: Looks like getHttpRequestMethod() should be added here.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -210,7 +211,7 @@ protected void setupConnection(Message message, Address address, HTTPClientPolic
             (String)message.get(Message.HTTP_REQUEST_METHOD);

nodes.bodyText: This file looks like it should not be changed with this PR.
This change should not be needed and this whole file can be removed from being changed in this PR.
This change should not be needed and this whole file can be removed from being changed in this PR.
Should remove these commented out System.out.println's from the code.
The cast here should not be needed.
should this call the new getFromHeaders method instead of getProtocolHeader?
No reason to leave the commented out code in.
This cast should not be needed.
Remove commented out code.  Same below.
Instead of commenting out just remove it.
Don't leave in the commented out code.
You will see why later, but should we just make this an Object[] and then have an static final int for each one of the properties for an index in that array for the property?

Again you will see later, but maybe this should be a HashMap with a key being the property name and the value being the int index in a property array.  Additionally you would need an static String[] with the properties.
This method is still missing change flags
The cast is not needed here if you update inMessage a few lines up to be of type MessageImpl instead of Mesage.
This isn't needed in the sub class.  Its existence in the super class is sufficient
This isn't needed in the sub class. Its existence in the super class is sufficient

This applies to keySet, entrySet and values.  Do we want to support this calling Iterator.remove methods on the returned Collections?  If so it would be a custom implementation of the Collection returned and the Iterator would be able to track where we are with the current key, value, entry and be able to do the remove method based off of that.  With us having an array of getter/setter properties it will be easier to track what should be removed on the Collection iterator.
If we keep this current mechanism, then we should make a copy of the Set that is returned for super.keySet() like you do in entrySet so we aren't modifying the parents returned Set object.
Should make a copy of the Map and then as you set fields instead of calling the super way of putting all, you should, remove them from the copy of the Map and only send the subset to the super.putAll

I think there are additional methods that need to be implemented:  size, clear, isEmpty, containsValue, equals, hashCode, getOrDefault, forEach, replaceAll, putIfAbsent, remove(Object, Object), replace, computeIfAbsent, computerIfPresent, compute, merge.  We may want to just implement them and have them return UnsupportedOperationException if we don't think they are called by CXF.
Either this should call super.getOrDefault or this whole method should just call getOrDefault to use the impl that is in this class.
Should check for NOT_FOUND here to avoid the .equals call.  Also you need to handle o being null or you are going to get a NullPointerException

This logic should be like the normal get method in this class.  Not sure why you aren't checking the propertyNames first.  You should use the keymap as well here like in get.   The method should be flipped and the last line be super.getOrDefault(key, d);
This should be .equals instead of == check. Need to handle null as well.
Again need to use .equals and need to handle null.
Again I recommend doing the == null check on oldValue instead of propertyValues[index] and then do oldValue.equals to reverse the equals.

I think this if / else can be simplified to:
propertyValues[index] = newValue == null ? NOT_FOUND : newValue;

If newValue is null it should set it to NOT_FOUND, i.e.
proeprtyValues[index] = newValue == null ? NOT_FOUND : newValue;
This will create an infinite loop.  clear() has the same issue.  You need to change to MessageImpl.this.size() and MessageImpl.this.clear();
Can you just use getOrDefault here like in other places instead of containsKey and get?  Will save doing a scan again

Similar to the HashMap for keySet, values and entrySet, you can just have an instance variable that defaults to null and then make a key set, value collection, or entry set and set it if it is null.  You don't need to make one every time it is called.
Not sure if this is called a lot, but for performance I think you can have this call putIfAbsent(key, v); instead of doing containsKey and put.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -297,5 +429,955 @@ void setContextualProperty(String key, Object v) {
             put(key, v);

nodes.bodyText: Can you remove this line and line 599 since they are now inside a new Liberty start/end block?
no need for the comment here or on line 272, since there is already a comment on line 271.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -268,7 +267,9 @@ public void invoke(final ServletConfig config,
 
         copyKnownRequestAttributes(req, inMessage);
 
-        inMessage.put(HttpServletResponse.class, resp); // Liberty change - reqd for SSE see LibertySseEventSinkImpl
+        //Liberty code change start

nodes.bodyText: I might be missing something, but I don't think these changes (this line, line 323, lines 327-328) are necessary.  IIUC, the only time that the MessageImpl is used is on line 340 which is already casted to a MessageImpl - and already surrounded by the change tags.

If I read this right, we are pulling in the WadlGenerator source file and updating the bnd file just for this change.  I don't think very many customers use Wadl (it's pretty much been replaced by Swagger/OpenAPI).  Are you seeing specific performance improvements in your benchmarks with this change?  If so, I'd probably update the benchmarks to use OpenAPI instead. :) If not, I'd say let's undo this change and the bnd change - it's one less divergence from the Apache CXF repo.

I was hoping that you wouldn't need to have the getGetters, getSetters, getRemoves, getContains in MessageImpl.  You can build that dynamically using reflection and it will be less fragile and the test can automatically pick up new getters, etc and fail tests when new methods are added.
This should be return e.equals(entry);
There shouldn't be a ", " at the end of the testpath.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -29,3 +30,7 @@ instrument.classesExcludes: org/apache/cxf/common/jaxb/*.class
   com.ibm.wsspi.org.osgi.service.component.annotations;version=latest,\
   com.ibm.websphere.org.osgi.service.cm;version=latest,\
   com.ibm.wsspi.org.osgi.core
+
+-testpath: \
+	../build.sharedResources/lib/junit/old/junit.jar;version=file, \

nodes.bodyText: This should be final
